title: Erdős Problem #941: Sums of Three Powerful Numbers
description: Are all large integers the sum of at most three powerful numbers (p | n → p² | n)? SOLVED: YES (Heath-Brown 1988). Every sufficiently large integer is the sum of at most 3 powerful numbers.

overview.historicalContext:
**Erdős Problem #941 (Sums of Three Powerful Numbers)**

**Origin:**
Erdős and Ivić posed this problem in 1986 at Oberwolfach: Are all sufficiently large integers the sum of at most three powerful numbers?

**Powerful Numbers:**
A number n is powerful (or squarefull) if every prime dividing n divides it at least twice: p | n → p² | n. Equivalently, n = a²b³ for some a, b ≥ 1.

**Heath-Brown's Proof (1988):**
Heath-Brown proved the affirmative answer using methods from the theory of ternary quadratic forms.

**Related Problems:**
- #940: Other variants of powerful representations
- #1107: Generalization to r-powerful numbers (p | n → p^r | n)
overview.problemStatement:
**Problem Statement (Solved)**

Are all large integers the sum of at most three powerful numbers?

A number n is powerful if p | n implies p² | n.

**Answer: YES** (Heath-Brown 1988)

Every sufficiently large positive integer is the sum of at most three powerful numbers.
